name: Zaheer Khan
bio: Zaheer Khan is a self-taught Bangladeshi chef with over 20 years of culinary experience. He's known for his innovative recipes, use of local ingredients, and social media presence. Khan has worked in various restaurants and hotels worldwide, won culinary awards, and judged cooking competitions. He's also involved in social and charitable causes, supporting NGOs and philanthropic endeavors.

dishes.name: Beef Tehari
dishes.description: Beef Tehari is a flavorful rice dish popular in Bangladesh and some regions of India. It is made with aromatic spices, tender beef, and fragrant Basmati rice.
instructions: Wash and soak Basmati rice in water for 30 minutes.
In a pressure cooker, heat ghee or oil and add sliced onions. Fry until they turn golden brown.
Add ginger, garlic, and green chilies. Fry for 2-3 minutes.
Add beef and fry until browned on all sides.
Add cumin seeds, coriander powder, turmeric powder, red chili powder, cinnamon powder, cardamom pods, bay leaves, and salt. Fry for 2-3 minutes.
Add soaked rice and fry for 2-3 minutes.
Add 4 cups of water and pressure cook for 10-15 minutes or until the rice and beef are cooked through.
Remove from heat and let the pressure release naturally.
Serve hot with raita and salad.

dishes.name: Dhakaiya Chicken Roast
dishes.description: Dhakaiya Chicken Roast is a classic Bangladeshi dish made with marinated chicken roasted in an oven or grill.
instructions: Marinate the chicken with yogurt, salt, and all the spices for at least 2-3 hours.
Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C).
In a pan, heat oil or ghee and fry chopped onions until they turn translucent.
Add ginger, garlic, and green chilies. Fry for 2-3 minutes.
Add marinated chicken and fry until browned on all sides.
Transfer the chicken to a baking tray and roast in the oven for 45-50 minutes or until fully cooked.
Remove from the oven and let it cool for 5-10 minutes before serving.
Serve hot with naan or rice.

dishes.name: Shorshe Ilish
dishes.description: Shorshe Ilish is a popular Bengali dish made with Hilsa fish in a mustard gravy. It is a delicacy in Bangladesh and some regions of India.
instructions: Grind yellow and black mustard seeds and green chilies into a fine paste.
Mix the mustard paste with turmeric powder, red chili powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, and salt.
Coat the Hilsa fish steaks with the mustard paste and marinate for at least 30 minutes.
Heat mustard oil in a pan and fry the marinated fish steaks until golden brown on both sides.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

dishes.name: Mutton Curry
dishes.description: Mutton Curry is a classic Indian and South Asian dish made with tender mutton meat cooked in a flavorful curry sauce.
instructions: In a pressure cooker, heat oil or ghee and fry chopped onions until they turn golden brown.
Add ginger, garlic, and green chilies. Fry for 2-3 minutes.
Add mutton pieces and fry until browned on all sides.
Add cumin seeds, coriander powder, turmeric powder, red chili powder, garam masala, bay leaves, and salt. Fry for 2-3 minutes.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they turn soft and mushy.
Add 2 cups of water and pressure cook for 15-20 minutes or until the mutton is cooked through.
Remove from heat and let the pressure release naturally.
Serve hot with steamed rice or Indian bread.

name: Shawkat Osman
bio: Osman Shawkat is a prominent Bangladeshi chef known for his fusion of traditional Bangladeshi flavors with modern techniques. He has won several culinary awards, worked in prestigious hotels and restaurants, and supports various charitable causes. Shawkat promotes locally sourced ingredients and traditional Bangladeshi cuisine.

name: Tony Khan
bio: Tony Karim is a renowned Bangladeshi chef who has achieved international recognition for his culinary skills. He is known for his contemporary take on traditional Bangladeshi cuisine and has worked in several renowned restaurants in London. He has received numerous accolades and awards for his cuisine, including being named Chef of the Year by The British Bangladeshi Who's Who. He has also been featured in various media outlets for his work, including The Guardian and BBC Good Food.

name: Shawkat Ali
bio: Chef Shawkat Ali is a renowned Bangladeshi chef known for his innovative approach to cooking that blends traditional Bangladeshi cuisine with modern techniques and ingredients. He has received numerous awards and accolades, including being named Chef of the Year at the Bangladesh Chef Association Awards. Chef Ali is dedicated to promoting Bangladeshi cuisine on a global level and is considered a pioneer in the field of Bangladeshi culinary arts.

name: Mamun Chowdhury
bio: Chef Mamun Chowdhury is a renowned Bangladeshi chef with over 20 years of experience in the culinary industry. He is known for creating unique and flavorful dishes that showcase the rich culinary traditions of Bangladesh. Chef Chowdhury has received several awards and accolades, including being named Best Chef in Bangladesh at the WACS competition. He is passionate about promoting Bangladeshi cuisine globally and has worked in several high-end restaurants and hotels both in Bangladesh and internationally.

name: Siddika Kabir
bio: Chef Siddika Kabir was a legendary Bangladeshi chef, nutritionist, and cooking instructor, who passed away in 2012 at the age of 86. She was widely regarded as an icon in the culinary world, and her contributions to the promotion and preservation of Bangladeshi cuisine are immeasurable. Chef Kabir authored several popular cookbooks, including the renowned Ranna Khaddo Pushti, which is considered a classic in Bangladeshi cuisine. She also hosted a popular cooking show on BTV, which aired for over 30 years, and educated millions of viewers on traditional Bangladeshi cooking techniques and nutrition. Chef Kabir received numerous awards and accolades throughout her career, including the Ekushey Padak in 1997, one of the highest civilian honors in Bangladesh. She remains a beloved figure in Bangladeshi culinary culture and is remembered for her dedication to preserving and promoting the cuisine for future generations.
